page.title: 02THE RHYMNEY COMMON-LANDSCAPE
page.content: The Rhymney Common is situated on the northernmost edge of the South Wales Coalfield.This is an upland area,where the limestone out-crops can be seen as a natural boundary between the rolling sandstone hills of Southern Powys and the coal measures of the industrial South.The Common itself is an area of typical limestone scenery.Coarse grass with scattered limestone boulders produces a stark , almost forbidding moorland landscape.Consquently colonisation has been slow.The few people living in the scattered small holdings on the Southern edge eke out a meagre agricultural living.The land itself,consisting of rough grassland growing on shallow earth over limestone,can only support the hardy Welsh Mountain sheep and ponies,which roam freely over the hillside.Even these require feeding in Winter.
